item.title: The trauma of implementation persisted.
item.description: A few weeks back, I promised a deeper dive into the top five implementation mistakes for both clients and consultants. Let’s address the biggest misstep for both groups: For consultants: Assuming you alone determine the project’s success or failure. For clients: Assuming the consulting team solely dictates the project’s success or failure. Taking sole responsibility for a project is problematic for both parties. Let’s illustrate with Suzy’s story. Suzy, a stellar consultant, is adored by her clients.

item.title: Once again, experiencing trauma from the implementation process.
item.description: Let’s delve into the second point from our list of implementation pitfalls. As a reminder, we’re discussing how “forgetting the importance of customer service during a demanding implementation” for consultants, and “treating the consulting team as adversaries rather than partners” for customers, can hinder success. These points might seem self-evident in writing, yet they’re often overlooked amidst the pressures of an implementation. This oversight can quickly sour a positive experience. Let’s examine the customer service aspect first.
